instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2494: What is 820-2494? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5_REG: What is PP3V3_S5_REG? PP3V3_S5_REG is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S5_LDO: What is PP5V_S5_LDO? PP5V_S5_LDO is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a S5 soft off state. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2494</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only first LED
threads.message:
Clean board just died suddenly.

First LED comes on with 12V are injected to <SIGNAL>PP12V_S5</SIGNAL> 
When power button is shorted nothing happens and <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> stays at 3.3V
No shorts found.

<SIGNAL>PP1V1_S5_REG</SIGNAL> - 1.1V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL> - 5V
<SIGNAL>PP12V_S5</SIGNAL> - 12.05V

Missing <SIGNAL>5VREG_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>

Im not very good with this old iMacs, any guidance will be greatly appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2494</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only first LED
threads.message:
Use S5010 pads for test, instead of power button.
If starts, then bad power button, connector, or cable.
Be sure <RESISTOR>R5010</RESISTOR> is good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2494</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only first LED
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R5010</RESISTOR> is good 1k
Diode mode on S5010:1/2 is same as J5010:1 so the connection is good
I am not using power button for testing, I am shorting J5010:1 to ground

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2494</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only first LED
threads.message: Then <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> MUST drop to 0V, when trigger S5010.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2494</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only first LED
threads.message: Ok now it does, sorry for the hold up, it does drop to 0.300V when I short  J5010:1 to ground, but only fist LED remains lid.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2494</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only first LED
threads.message:
Check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> at same time.
If present, check for pulse at Pin 1 of <CHIP>U7300</CHIP>; this chip fails a lot.

Do you get correct voltage at L7920?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2494</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only first LED
threads.message:
L7920 1.1V both ends

When I short J5010:1 to ground I get 3.3V on <CHIP>U7300</CHIP>:1 but <CHIP>U7300</CHIP>:12 still 0V even thou this chip was making that voltage on the donor board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2494</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only first LED
threads.message: I put the chip back on the donor board and now it is dead, looks like the temperature when removing it is killing it or then I install it on the other board that board is killing it, Im a little confused here...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2494</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only first LED
threads.message:
Check <TRANSISTOR>Q7330</TRANSISTOR>, <DIODE>D7301</DIODE>, <RESISTOR>R7324</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7326</CAPACITOR>.
Diode mode to ground at L7320?
